meanings.definition: To lead or guide in the wrong direction.
meanings.sent1: The faulty map mislighted the hikers, causing them to get lost.
meanings.sent2: She didn't want to mislight her friend, so she gave clear directions.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous squirrel mislighted the other animals by leading them to a fake stash of acorns.
meanings.sent4: His overconfidence mislighted him into thinking he could navigate the maze blindfolded.
meanings.sent5: The flickering torchlight mislighted the path, making it hard to see the way ahead.

meanings.sent1: The con artist tried to mislight the old lady into buying a fake painting.
meanings.sent2: It is unethical to mislight customers about the quality of a product.
meanings.sent3: The magician's trick was to mislight the audience into believing he could fly.
meanings.sent4: Her charming smile could mislight anyone into trusting her instantly.
meanings.sent5: The fake news article was designed to mislight readers into believing a false narrative.

meanings.sent1: The mislight in the report led to a misunderstanding among the team.
meanings.sent2: It's important to verify sources to avoid spreading mislight.
meanings.sent3: The mislight in the advertisement made the product seem better than it actually was.
meanings.sent4: The mislight in the contract caused a legal dispute between the parties.
meanings.sent5: She was shocked to discover the mislight in the historical document she had been studying.
